title:
Estimates effective population size using the Linkage Disequilibrium
method based on NeEstimator (V2) ‚Äî gl.LDNe
text: x Name genlight object containing SNP data [required]. outfile File name output file  results Neestimator 2 [default 'genepopLD.txt']. outpath Path save output file. Use outpath=getwd() outpath='.' calling function direct output files working  directory [default tempdir(), mandated CRAN]. neest.path Path folder NE2-1 file. Please note 3 different executables depending OS: Ne2-1.exe (=Windows), Ne2-1M (=Mac), Ne2-1L (=Linux). need point folder (function recognise OS running) [default getwd()]. critical (vector ) Critical values used remove alleles based minor allele frequency. can done using gl.filter.maf function, therefore default set 0 (loci removed). run MAF 0 MAF 0.05 time specify: critical = c(0,0.05) [default 0]. singleton.rm Whether remove singleton alleles [default TRUE]. mating Formula Random mating='random' monogamy= 'monogamy' [default 'random']. plot.Specify plot produced [default TRUE]. plot_theme User specified theme [default theme_dartR()]. plot_colors_pop discrete palette population colors list many colors populations dataset [default discrete_palette]. save2tmp TRUE, saves ggplots listings session temporary directory (tempdir) [default FALSE]. verbose Verbosity: 0, silent fatal errors; 1, begin end; 2, progress log; 3, progress results summary; 5, full report [default 2, unless specified using gl.set.verbosity].

title:
Assign an individual of unknown provenance to population based on 
Mahalanobis Distance ‚Äî gl.assign.mahalanobis
text: three considerations assignment. First, consider populations unknown private alleles. Private alleles indication unknown belong target population (provided sample size adequate, say >=10). can evaluated  gl.assign.pa(). next step consider PCoA plot populations private alleles detected. position unknown relation confidence ellipses plotted script basis narrowing list putative source populations. can evaluated  gl.assign.pca(). third step (delivered script) consider assignment  probabilities based squared Generalised Linear Distance  (Mahalanobis distance) unknown centroid population,  consider probability associated quantile using  Chisquare approximation. effect, index takes account position  unknown relation confidence envelope selected  dimensions ordination. larger assignment probability,  greater confidence assignment. dim.limit set 2, correspond dimensions used gl.assign.pa(), output provides ranking final set putative source populations. dim.limit set > 2, script provides basis narrowing set putative populations.unknown individual extreme outlier, say less 0.001 probability population  membership (0.999 confidence envelope), associated population  can eliminated consideration. Warning: gl.assign.mahal() treats specified dimension equally, without regard percentage variation explained ordination.  unknown outlier lower dimension explanatory variance , say, 0.1 dimensions ordination. approaches provides evidence, none 100 need interpreted cautiously. deciding assignment, script considers individual outlier respect particular population alpha = 0.001 default

what:
Aligns nucleotides sequences against those present in a target database 
using blastn ‚Äî gl.blast
title:
Aligns nucleotides sequences against those present in a target database 
using blastn ‚Äî gl.blast
text: Basic Local Alignment Search Tool (BLAST; Altschul et al., 1990 &  1997) sequence comparison algorithm optimized speed used search  sequence databases optimal local alignments query. function  creates fasta files, creates databases run BLAST, runs blastn filters  results obtain best hit per sequence. function can used run BLAST alignment short-read (DArTseq  data) long-read sequences (Illumina, PacBio... etc). can use  reference genomes NCBI, genomes private collection, contigs,  scaffolds genetic sequence like use  reference.

title:
Aligns nucleotides sequences against those present in a target database 
using blastn ‚Äî gl.blast
code: gl.blast(   x,   ref_genome,   task = "megablast",   Percentage_identity = 70,   Percentage_overlap = 0.8,   bitscore = 50,   number_of_threads = 2,   verbose = NULL )

title:
Aligns nucleotides sequences against those present in a target database 
using blastn ‚Äî gl.blast
text: x Either genlight object containing column named 'TrimmedSequence' containing sequence SNPs (sequence tag) trimmed adapters provided DArT; path fasta file query sequences [required]. ref_genome Path reference genome fasta fna format [required]. task Four different tasks supported: 1) ‚Äúmegablast‚Äù, similar sequences (e.g, sequencing errors), 2) ‚Äúdc-megablast‚Äù, typically used inter-species comparisons, 3) ‚Äúblastn‚Äù, traditional program used inter-species comparisons, 4) ‚Äúblastn-short‚Äù, optimized sequences less 30 nucleotides [default 'megablast']. Percentage_identity sensitive reliable measure sequence similarity, however reasonable proxy evolutionary distance. evolutionary distance associated 10 percent change Percentage_identity much greater longer distances. Thus, change 80 ‚Äì 70 percent identity might reflect divergence 200 million years earlier time, change 30 percent 20 percent might correspond billion year divergence time change [default 70]. Percentage_overlap Calculated alignment length divided query length subject length (whichever shortest two lengths, .e.  length / min(qlen,slen) ) [default 0.8]. bitscore rule--thumb inferring homology, bit score 50 almost always significant [default 50]. number_of_threads Number threads (CPUs) use blastn search [default 2]. verbose verbose= 0, silent fatal errors; 1, begin end; 2, progress log ; 3, progress results summary; 5, full report [default 2 specified using gl.set.verbosity]

title:
Aligns nucleotides sequences against those present in a target database 
using blastn ‚Äî gl.blast
text: input genlight object: returns genlight object one  hit per sequence merged slot $$loc.metrics. input  fasta file: returns dataframe one hit per sequence.

title:
Aligns nucleotides sequences against those present in a target database 
using blastn ‚Äî gl.blast
text: Installing BLAST can download BLAST installs :  https://ftp.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/blast/executables/blast+/LATEST/ important install BLAST path contain spaces  function work. Running BLAST Four different tasks supported: ‚Äúmegablast‚Äù,  similar sequences (e.g, sequencing errors) ‚Äúdc-megablast‚Äù, typically  used inter-species comparisons ‚Äúblastn‚Äù, traditional program  used inter-species comparisons ‚Äúblastn-short‚Äù, optimized  sequences less 30 nucleotides    running   BLAST alignment  similar  sequences,   example  Turtle  Genome  Vs Turtle Sequences, recommended parameters  : task = ‚Äúmegablast‚Äù, Percentage_identity = 70, Percentage_overlap =  0.8  bitscore = 50. running BLAST alignment highly dissimilar sequences  probably looking sex linked  hits  distantly  related  species,    aligning example sequences Chicken Genome Vs  Bassiana, recommended parameters : task = ‚Äúdc-megablast‚Äù,  Percentage_identity = 50, Percentage_overlap =  0.01 bitscore = 30. aware running BLAST might take long time (.e. days) depending  size query, size database number threads  selected computer. BLAST output BLAST output formatted table using output format 6, columns  defined following order: qseqid - Query Seq-id sacc - Subject accession stitle - Subject Title qseq - Aligned  part query sequence sseq - Aligned part subject sequence nident - Number identical matches mismatch - Number mismatches pident - Percentage identical matches length - Alignment  length evalue - Expect value bitscore - Bit score qstart -  Start alignment query qend - End alignment query sstart - Start alignment subject send - End alignment  subject gapopen - Number gap openings gaps - Total number  gaps qlen - Query sequence length slen - Subject sequence length PercentageOverlap - length / min(qlen,slen) Databases containing unfiltered aligned sequences, filtered aligned  sequences one hit per sequence saved temporal directory  (tempdir) can accessed function  gl.print.reports listed function  gl.list.reports. Note can accessed  current R session tempdir cleared time R session  closed. BLAST filtering BLAST output filtered ordering hits sequence first  highest percentage identity, highest percentage overlap  highest bitscore. one hit per sequence kept based  selection criteria.

title:
Aligns nucleotides sequences against those present in a target database 
using blastn ‚Äî gl.blast
text: Altschul, S. F., Gish, W., Miller, W., Myers, E. W., & Lipman, D.  J. (1990). Basic local alignment search tool. Journal molecular biology,  215(3), 403-410. Altschul, S. F., Madden, T. L., Sch√§ffer, . ., Zhang, J., Zhang,  Z., Miller, W., & Lipman, D. J. (1997). Gapped BLAST PSI-BLAST: new  generation protein database search programs. Nucleic acids research,  25(17), 3389-3402. Pearson, W. R. (2013). introduction sequence similarity  (‚Äúhomology‚Äù) searching. Current protocols bioinformatics, 42(1), 3-1.

 expectations and amends it to comply if necessary ‚Äî gl.compliance.check
text: genlight object used dartR number requirements allow functions within package operate correctly. genlight object comprises: SNP genotypes Tag Presence/Absence data (SilicoDArT); associated dataframe (gl@$loc.metrics) containing locus metrics (e.g. Call Rate, Repeatability, etc); associated dataframe (gl@$ind.metrics) containing individual/sample metrics (e.g. sex, latitude (=lat), longitude(=lon), etc); specimen identity field (indNames(gl)) unique labels applied individual/sample; population assignment (popNames) individual/specimen; Flags indicate whether calculable locus metrics updated.

NN Number next neighbours recommendation 8 [required]. verbose Verbosity: 0, silent fatal errors; 1, begin end; 2, progress log ; 3, progress results summary; 5, full report [default 2, unless specified using gl.set.verbosity].

title: Calculates cost distances for a given landscape (resistance matrix) ‚Äî gl.costdistances
code: if (FALSE) { data(possums.gl) library(raster)  #needed for that example landscape.sim <- readRDS(system.file('extdata','landscape.sim.rdata',  package='dartR')) #calculate mean centers of individuals per population xy <- apply(possums.gl@other$xy, 2, function(x) tapply(x, pop(possums.gl),  mean)) cd <- gl.costdistances(landscape.sim, xy, method='leastcost', NN=8) round(cd,3) }

title:
Provides descriptive stats and plots to diagnose potential problems
  with Hardy-Weinberg proportions ‚Äî gl.diagnostics.hwe
text: function initially runs gl.report.hwe reports ternary plots. remaining outputs follow recommendations  Waples (2015) paper De Mee√ªs 2018. include: histogram distribution p-values HWE tests. distribution roughly uniform across equal-sized bins. bar plot observed expected (null expectation) number significant HWE tests locus multiple populations (, x-axis shows whether locus results significant 1, 2, ..., n populations. y axis count occurrences. zero value x-axis shows number non-significant tests). HWE tests significant chance alone, observed expected number HWE tests roughly similar distribution. scatter plot linear regression Fst Fis,  averaged across subpopulations. De Mee√ªs 2018 suggests case Null alleles, strong positive relationship expected (together Fis standard error much larger Fst standard error, see ). Note, scatter plot Waples 2015 presents paper. lower right corner plot, Pearson correlation coefficient reported. Fis Fst (averaged loci subpopulations) standard errors also printed screen reported returned list (stdErr=TRUE). computed  Jackknife method loci (See De Mee√ªs 2007 details  computed) may take time computations complete.  De Mee√ªs 2018 suggests global significant heterozygosity  deficit: - correlation Fis Fst strongly positive, StdErrFis >> StdErrFst, Null alleles likely cause. - correlation Fis Fst ~0 mildly positive, StdErrFis > StdErrFst, Wahlund may cause. - correlation Fis Fst ~0, StdErrFis ~ StdErrFst, selfing sib mating cause. important realise statistics suggest pattern (pointers). absence conclusive evidence absence problem,  presence confirm cause problem. table number observed expected significant HWE tests reported population, indicating whether due heterozygosity excess deficiency. can used clue potential problems (e.g. deficiency might due Wahlund effect, presence null alleles non-random sampling; excess might due sex linkage different selection sexes, demographic changes small Ne. See Table 1 Wapples 2015). last two columns table generated function report chisquare values associated p-values. Chisquare computed following Fisher's procedure global test (Fisher 1970). basically tests whether least one test truly significant series tests conducted (De Mee√ªs et al 2009).

Expected FST neutrality (Takahata, 1983) calculated : FST=1/(4Nem(n/(n-1))^2+1), Ne effective populations size individual subpopulation, m dispersal rate n number subpopulations (always 2).

text: x Name genlight object containing SNP data [required]. subset Way group individuals perform H-W tests. Either vector population names, '', '' (see details) [default '']. n.pop.threshold minimum number populations locus  H-W proportions removed [default 1]. method_sig Method determining statistical significance:  'ChiSquare' 'Exact' [default 'Exact']. multi_comp Whether adjust p-values multiple comparisons [default FALSE]. multi_comp_method Method adjust p-values multiple comparisons: 'holm', 'hochberg', 'hommel', 'bonferroni', 'BH', '', 'fdr' (see details) [default 'fdr']. alpha_val Level significance testing [default 0.05]. pvalue_type Type p-value used Exact method. Either 'dost','selome','midp' (see details) [default 'midp']. cc_val continuity correction applied ChiSquare test [default 0.5]. min_sample_size Minimum number individuals per population perform H-W tests [default 5]. verbose Verbosity: 0, silent fatal errors; 1, begin end; 2, progress log; 3, progress results summary; 5, full report [default 2, unless specified using gl.set.verbosity].

title:
Filters loci that show significant departure from Hardy-Weinberg

text: genlight object loci departing significantly H-W proportions removed.

title:
Filters loci that show significant departure from Hardy-Weinberg
 Equilibrium ‚Äî gl.filter.hwe
text: several factors can cause deviations Hardy-Weinberg  proportions including: mutation, finite population size, selection,  population structure, age structure, assortative mating, sex linkage,  nonrandom sampling genotyping errors. Therefore, testing  Hardy-Weinberg proportions process involves careful  evaluation results, good place start Waples (2015). Note tests H-W proportions valid population  substructure (assuming random mating) sufficient power  sufficient sample size (n individuals > 15). Populations can defined three ways: Merging populations dataset using subset = ''. Within population separately using: subset = ''. Within selected populations using example: subset =  c('pop1','pop2'). Two different statistical methods test deviations Hardy Weinberg proportions: classical chi-square test (method_sig='ChiSquare') based function HWChisq R package HardyWeinberg. default continuity correction applied (cc_val=0.5). continuity correction can turned (specifying cc_val=0), example cases extreme allele frequencies continuity correction can lead excessive type 1 error rates. exact test (method_sig='Exact') based exact calculations contained function HWExactStats R package HardyWeinberg, described Wigginton  et al. (2005). exact test recommended cases (Wigginton  et al., 2005). Three different methods estimate p-values (pvalue_type) Exact test can used: 'dost' p-value computed twice tail area one-sided test. 'selome' p-value computed sum probabilities samples less equally likely current sample. 'midp', p-value computed half probability current sample + probabilities samples extreme. standard exact p-value overly conservative, particular small minor allele frequencies. mid p-value ameliorates problem bringing rejection rate closer nominal level, price occasionally exceeding nominal level (Graffelman & Moreno, 2013). Correction multiple tests can applied using following methods based function p.adjust: 'holm' also known sequential Bonferroni technique  (Rice, 1989). method greater statistical power standard Bonferroni  test, however method becomes stringent many tests performed many real deviations null hypothesis can go undetected  (Waples, 2015). 'hochberg' based Hochberg, 1988. 'hommel' based Hommel, 1988. method powerful Hochberg's, difference usually small. 'bonferroni' p-values multiplied number tests. method stringent therefore reduced power detect multiple departures null hypothesis. 'BH' based Benjamini & Hochberg, 1995. '' based Benjamini & Yekutieli, 2001. first four methods designed give strong control family-wise error rate. last two methods control false discovery rate (FDR), expected proportion false discoveries among rejected hypotheses. false discovery rate less stringent condition family-wise error rate, methods powerful others, especially number tests large. number tests adjustment multiple comparisons number populations times number loci. v2.1 gl.filter.hwe takes argument  n.pop.threshold. n.pop.threshold > 1 loci removed  concurrently  significant (adjustment applied) hwe >=  n.pop.threshold > 1.

title:
Filters loci that show significant departure from Hardy-Weinberg
 Equilibrium ‚Äî gl.filter.hwe
text: Benjamini, Y., Yekutieli, D. (2001). control false  discovery rate multiple testing dependency. Annals Statistics,  29, 1165‚Äì1188. Graffelman, J. (2015). Exploring Diallelic Genetic Markers: Hardy Weinberg Package. Journal Statistical Software 64:1-23. Graffelman, J. & Morales-Camarena, J. (2008). Graphical tests Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium based ternary plot. Human Heredity  65:77-84. Graffelman, J., & Moreno, V. (2013). mid p-value exact tests Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium. Statistical applications genetics  molecular biology, 12(4), 433-448. Hochberg, Y. (1988). sharper Bonferroni procedure multiple tests  significance. Biometrika, 75, 800‚Äì803. Hommel, G. (1988). stagewise rejective multiple test procedure based  modified Bonferroni test. Biometrika, 75, 383‚Äì386. Rice, W. R. (1989). Analyzing tables statistical tests. Evolution,  43(1), 223-225. Waples, R. S. (2015). Testing Hardy‚ÄìWeinberg proportions: lost plot?. Journal heredity, 106(1), 1-19. Wigginton, J.E., Cutler, D.J., & Abecasis, G.R. (2005). Note Exact Tests Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium. American Journal Human Genetics 76:887-893.

title:

 other$loc.metrics in a genlight {adegenet} object ‚Äî gl.filter.locmetric
text: fields included dartR, short description, found . Optionally, user can also set /filter adding vector $$loc.metrics shown example. SnpPosition - position (zero position 1) sequence tag defined SNP variant base. CallRate - proportion samples genotype call non-missing (, '-' ). OneRatioRef - proportion samples genotype score 0. OneRatioSnp - proportion samples genotype score 2. FreqHomRef - proportion samples homozygous Reference allele. FreqHomSnp - proportion samples homozygous Alternate (SNP) allele. FreqHets - proportion samples score heterozygous, , scored 1. PICRef - polymorphism information content (PIC) Reference allele. PICSnp - polymorphism information content (PIC) SNP. AvgPIC - average polymorphism information content (PIC) Reference SNP alleles. AvgCountRef - sum tag read counts samples, divided number samples non-zero tag read counts, Reference allele  row. AvgCountSnp - sum tag read counts samples, divided number samples non-zero tag read counts, Alternate (SNP)  allele row. RepAvg - proportion technical replicate assay pairs marker score consistent.

Similarly, always  sensible choice run function using .pop=TRUE allele  rare population may common , (possible)  allele frequencies depend sample size within population.  purpose filtering MAF remove possible spurious alleles  (.e. sequencing errors), perhaps better filter based number  times allele observed (MAC, Minimum Allele Count),  assumption allele observed >MAC, fairly rare  error. v2.1 threshold can take values > 1. case,  interpreted threshold MAC.

text: script deletes monomorphic loci genlight {adegenet} object DArT dataset monomorphic loci, can arise, along loci scored NA, populations individuals deleted. Retaining monomorphic loci unnecessarily increases size dataset affect calculations. Note SNP data, NAs likely represent null alleles; tag presence/absence data, NAs represent missing values (presence/absence reliably scored)

title: Filters monomorphic loci, including those with all NAs ‚Äî gl.filter.monomorphs
code: gl.filter.monomorphs(x, verbose = NULL)

title: Filters monomorphic loci, including those with all NAs ‚Äî gl.filter.monomorphs
text: x Name input genlight object [required]. verbose Verbosity: 0, silent fatal errors; 1, begin end; 2, progress log; 3, progress results summary; 5, full report [default 2, unless specified using gl.set.verbosity].

Default 0, means read.depth taken account [default 0]. t.het Tolerance heterogametic sex, t.het=0.05 means 5% heterogametic sex can homozygous still regarded  consistent sex specific marker [default 0.1]. t.hom Tolerance homogametic sex, t.hom=0.05 means 5% homogametic sex can heterozygous still regarded consistent sex specific marker [default 0.1]. t.pres Tolerance presence, t.pres=0.05 means silicodart marker can present either sexes still regarded  sex-linked marker [default 0.1]. plot.Creates plot shows heterozygosity males females loci regarded consistent sex specific marker  [default TRUE]. plot_theme Theme plot. See Details options [default theme_dartR()]. plot_colors List three color names sex-linked loci, sex-linked loci area sex-linked loci appear  [default three_colors]. verbose Verbosity: 0, silent fatal errors; 1, begin end; 2,  progress log; 3, progress results summary; 5, full report  [default NULL, unless specified using gl.set.verbosity].

title: Performs least-cost path analysis based on a friction matrix ‚Äî gl.genleastcost
text: function calculates pairwise distances (Euclidean, cost path  distances genetic distances) populations using friction matrix   spatial genind object. genind object needs coordinates   projected coordinate system friction matrix. friction   matrix can either single raster stack several layers.   stack provided specified cost distance calculated layer    stack. output function can used functions    wassermann    lgrMMRR test significance    layer genetic structure.

title: Performs least-cost path analysis based on a friction matrix ‚Äî gl.genleastcost
code: gl.genleastcost(   x,   fric.raster,   gen.distance,   NN = NULL,   pathtype = "leastcost",   plotpath = TRUE,   theta = 1,   verbose = NULL )

title: Performs least-cost path analysis based on a friction matrix ‚Äî gl.genleastcost
text: x spatial genind object. See ?popgenreport provide coordinates genind objects [required]. fric.raster friction matrix [required]. gen.distance Specification genetic distance method used calculate pairwise genetic distances populations ( 'D', 'Gst.Nei', 'Gst.Hedrick') individuals ('Smouse', 'Kosman', 'propShared')  [required]. NN Number neighbours used calculating cost distance (possible values 4, 8 16). default NULL value provided pathtype='leastcost'. NN=8 commonly used. aware  linear structures may cause artefacts least-cost paths, therefore  inspect actual least-cost paths provided output [default NULL]. pathtype Type cost distance calculated (based function gdistance package. Available distances 'leastcost', 'commute'  'rSPDistance'. See functions gdistance package futher  explanations. path type set 'leastcost' paths also  pathlength returned [default 'leastcost']. plotpath switch least cost paths plotted (works pathtype='leastcost'. aware slows computation, recommended check least cost paths visually. theta value needed rSPDistance function. See rSPDistance package gdistance [default 1]. verbose Verbosity: 0, silent fatal errors; 1, begin end; 2, progress log; 3, progress results summary; 5, full report [default 2, unless specified using gl.set.verbosity].

title: Performs least-cost path analysis based on a friction matrix ‚Äî gl.genleastcost
text: Returns list consists four pairwise distance matrices (Euclidean, Cost, length path genetic) actual paths spatial  line objects.

text: Bernd Gruber (bugs? Post https://groups.google.com/d/forum/dartr)

title: Performs least-cost path analysis based on a friction matrix ‚Äî gl.genleastcost
code: if (FALSE) { data(possums.gl) library(raster)  #needed for that example landscape.sim <- readRDS(system.file('extdata','landscape.sim.rdata',  package='dartR')) glc <- gl.genleastcost(x=possums.gl,fric.raster=landscape.sim , gen.distance = 'D', NN=8, pathtype = 'leastcost',plotpath = TRUE) library(PopGenReport) PopGenReport::wassermann(eucl.mat = glc$eucl.mat, cost.mat = glc$cost.mats,   gen.mat = glc$gen.mat) lgrMMRR(gen.mat = glc$gen.mat, cost.mats = glc$cost.mats,   eucl.mat = glc$eucl.mat) }

title: Calculates an identity by descent matrix ‚Äî gl.grm

Individual names shown margins heatmap colors  represent different populations.

title: Represents a genomic relationship matrix (GRM) as a network ‚Äî gl.grm.network
text: gl.grm.network function takes genomic relationship matrix (GRM)  generated gl.grm function represent relationship among  individuals dataset network diagram. generate GRM,  function gl.grm uses function .mat package rrBLUP, implements  approach developed Endelman Jannink (2012). GRM estimate proportion alleles two individuals  common. generated estimating covariance genotypes   two individuals, .e. much genotypes two individuals   correspond . covariance depends probability    alleles random locus identical state (IBS). Two alleles     IBS represent allele. Two alleles identical     descent (IBD) one physical copy     physical copies ancestral allele. Note IBD complicated     determine. IBD implies IBS, conversely. However, number      SNPs dataset increases, mean probability IBS approaches       mean probability IBD. follows -diagonal elements GRM two times  kinship coefficient, .e. probability two alleles random locus  drawn two individuals IBD. Additionally, diagonal elements   GRM 1+f, f inbreeding coefficient individual,    .e. probability two alleles random locus IBD. Choosing meaningful threshold represent relationship  individuals tricky IBD absolute state relative  reference population generally little information   can estimate kinship pair individuals relative   quantity. deal , can use average inbreeding   coefficient diagonal elements reference value. ,   function subtracts 1 mean diagonal elements GRM.   second step, -diagonal elements divided 2, finally,    mean diagonal elements subtracted -diagonal element    dividing 2. approach similar one used    Goudet et al. (2018). table modified Speed & Balding (2015) showing kinship values,  confidence intervals (CI), different relationships   used guide choosing relatedness threshold function. |Relationship|Kinship|95 |Identical twins/clones/individual     | 0.5     |        -         | |Sibling/Parent-Offspring                   | 0.25    |    (0.204, 0.296)| |Half-sibling                               | 0.125   |    (0.092, 0.158)| |First cousin                               | 0.062   |    (0.038, 0.089)| |Half-cousin                                | 0.031   |    (0.012, 0.055)| |Second cousin                              | 0.016   |    (0.004, 0.031)| |Half-second cousin                         | 0.008   |    (0.001, 0.020)| |Third cousin                               | 0.004   |    (0.000, 0.012)| |Unrelated                                  | 0       |        -         | Four layout options implemented function: 'fr' Fruchterman-Reingold layout  layout_with_fr (package igraph) 'kk' Kamada-Kawai layout layout_with_kk (package igraph) 'gh' Graphopt layout layout_with_graphopt (package igraph) 'mds' Multidimensional scaling layout layout_with_mds (package igraph)

text: function performs isolation distance analysis based Mantel test also produces isolation distance plot. genlight object coordinates provided, Euclidean genetic distance matrices calculated. #'

title: Performs isolation by distance analysis ‚Äî gl.ibd
code: gl.ibd(   x = NULL,   distance = "Fst",   coordinates = "latlon",   Dgen = NULL,   Dgeo = NULL,   Dgeo_trans = "Dgeo",   Dgen_trans = "Dgen",   permutations = 999,   plot.out = TRUE,   paircols = NULL,   plot_theme = theme_dartR(),   save2tmp = FALSE,   verbose = NULL )

title: Performs isolation by distance analysis ‚Äî gl.ibd
text: x Genlight object. provided standard analysis Fst/1-Fst log(distance) performed [required]. distance Type distance calculated used analysis. Can either population based 'Fst' [stamppFst], 'D' [stamppNeisD] individual based 'propShared',  [gl.propShared], 'euclidean' [gl.dist.ind, method='Euclidean'] [default "Fst"]. coordinates Can either 'latlon', 'xy' two column data.frame column names 'lat','lon', 'x', 'y'). Coordinates provided via gl@$latlon ['latlon'] via gl@$xy ['xy']. latlon data projected meters using Mercator system [google maps] xy distance directly calculated coordinates. Dgen Genetic distance matrix genlight object provided [default NULL]. Dgeo Euclidean distance matrix genlight object provided [default NULL]. Dgeo_trans Transformation used Euclidean distances. See Dgen_trans [default "Dgeo"]. Dgen_trans can provide formula transform genetic distance. transformation can applied formula using Dgen  variable transformed. example: Dgen_trans = 'Dgen/(1-Dgen)'.   valid R expression can used [default 'Dgen', identity function.] permutations Number permutations Mantel test [default 999]. plot.isolation distance plot returned [default TRUE]. paircols pairwise dots colored 'pop'ulation/'ind'ividual pairs [default 'pop']. can color pairwise individuals pairwise  population colors. plot_theme Theme plot. See details options [default theme_dartR()]. save2tmp TRUE, saves ggplots listings session temporary directory (tempdir) [default FALSE]. verbose Verbosity: 0, silent fatal errors; 1, begin end; 2, progress log ; 3, progress results summary; 5, full report [default 2 specified using gl.set.verbosity].

title: Performs isolation by distance analysis ‚Äî gl.ibd
text: Returns list following components: Dgen (genetic distance matrix), Dgeo (Euclidean distance matrix), Mantel (statistics Mantel test).

title: Performs isolation by distance analysis ‚Äî gl.ibd
text: Currently pairwise Fst D populations 1-propShared Euclidean distance individuals implemented. Coordinates expected lat long converted Google Earth Mercator projection. coordinates already projected, provide x@$xy slot. can provide also genetic Euclidean distance matrices. function based code provided adegenet tutorial (http://adegenet.r-forge.r-project.org/files/tutorial-basics.pdf), using functions  mantel (package vegan), stamppFst, stamppNeisD (package StAMPP) gl.propShared gl.dist.ind. transformation need dismo package installed. new feature can plot pairwise relationship using double colored points (paircols=TRUE). Pairwise relationship can visualised via populations individuals, depending distance calculated. Please note: Often problem arises, individual based distance calculated (e.g. propShared) individuals identical coordinates results distances zero pairs individuals. standard transformation [log(Dgeo)] used, results infinite value, trying calculate'log(0)'. avoid , easiest fix change transformation log(Dgeo) log(Dgeo+1) add "noise" coordinates individuals (e.g. +- 1m, aware use lat lon rather want add +0.00001 degrees ).

title: Performs isolation by distance analysis ‚Äî gl.ibd
text: Rousset, F. (1997). Genetic differentiation estimation gene flow F-statistics isolation distance. Genetics, 145(4), 1219-1228.

title: Performs isolation by distance analysis ‚Äî gl.ibd

Generating entire set.  #>   Coordinates used from: x@other$latlon (Mercator transformed)  #>   Transformation of Dgeo: Dgeo  #>   Genetic distance: Fst  #>   Tranformation of Dgen:  Dgen  #>  #> Mantel statistic based on Pearson's product-moment correlation  #>  #> Call: #> vegan::mantel(xdis = Dgen, ydis = Dgeo, permutations = permutations,      na.rm = TRUE)  #>  #> Mantel statistic r: 0.6683  #>       Significance: 0.14167  #>  #> Upper quantiles of permutations (null model): #>   90%   95% 97.5%   99%  #> 0.711 0.765 0.804 0.828  #> Permutation: free #> Number of permutations: 119 #>  #>  #> Completed: gl.ibd  #>  #>  #because of speed only the first 100 loci ibd <- gl.ibd(bandicoot.gl[,1:100], Dgeo_trans='log(Dgeo)' ,Dgen_trans='Dgen/(1-Dgen)') #> Analysis performed on the genlight object. #> Coordinates transformed to Mercator (google) projection to calculate distances in meters. #>  #> 'nperm' >= set of all permutations: complete enumeration. #> Set of permutations < 'minperm'. Generating entire set.  #>   Coordinates used from: x@other$latlon (Mercator transformed)  #>   Transformation of Dgeo: log(Dgeo)  #>   Genetic distance: Fst  #>   Tranformation of Dgen:  Dgen/(1-Dgen)  #>  #> Mantel statistic based on Pearson's product-moment correlation  #>  #> Call: #> vegan::mantel(xdis = Dgen, ydis = Dgeo, permutations = permutations,      na.rm = TRUE)  #>  #> Mantel statistic r: 0.5945  #>       Significance: 0.16667  #>  #> Upper quantiles of permutations (null model): #>   90%   95% 97.5%   99%  #> 0.683 0.737 0.779 0.815  #> Permutation: free #> Number of permutations: 119 #>  #>  #> Completed: gl.ibd  #>  #>  #because of speed only the first 10 individuals) ibd <- gl.ibd(bandicoot.gl[1:10,], distance='euclidean', paircols='pop', Dgeo_trans='Dgeo') #> Analysis performed on the genlight object. #> Coordinates transformed to Mercator (google) projection to calculate distances in meters. #>   #>   Coordinates used from: x@other$latlon (Mercator transformed)  #>   Transformation of Dgeo: Dgeo  #>   Genetic distance: euclidean  #>   Tranformation of Dgen:  Dgen  #>  #> Mantel statistic based on Pearson's product-moment correlation  #>  #> Call: #> vegan::mantel(xdis = Dgen, ydis = Dgeo, permutations = permutations,      na.rm = TRUE)  #>  #> Mantel statistic r: 0.3406  #>       Significance: 0.013  #>  #> Upper quantiles of permutations (null model): #>   90%   95% 97.5%   99%  #> 0.210 0.267 0.301 0.349  #> Permutation: free #> Number of permutations: 999 #>  #>  #> Completed: gl.ibd  #>  #>

text: x Name genlight object containing SNP presence-absence data [required]. method Imputation method, either "frequency" "HW" "neighbour"  "random" [default "HW"]. fill.residual residual missing values remaining  imputation set 0, 1, 2 random, taking account global allele  frequencies particular locus [default TRUE]. parallel logical indicating whether multiple cores -available- used computations (TRUE), (FALSE); requires package parallel installed [default FALSE]. verbose Verbosity: 0, silent fatal errors; 1, begin end; 2, progress log ; 3, progress results summary; 5, full report [default 2 specified using gl.set.verbosity].

title: Imputates missing data ‚Äî gl.impute
text: genlight object missing data imputed.

title: Imputates missing data ‚Äî gl.impute
text: recommend imputation performed sampling locations, aggregation. Imputation achieved replacing missing values using either two methods: "frequency", genotypes scored missing locus individual  imputed using average allele frequencies locus   population individual drawn. "HW", genotypes scored missing locus individual  imputed sampling random assuming Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium. Applies  genotype data. "neighbour", substitute missing values focal individual  values taken nearest neighbour. Repeat next nearest  missing values replaced. "random", missing data substituted random values (0, 1 2). nearest neighbour one smallest Euclidean distance    dataset. advantage approach works regardless many   individuals population focal individual belongs,   displacement individual haphazard opposed : () Drawing individual toward population centroid (HW Frequency). (b) Drawing individual toward global centroid (glPCA). Note loci missing individuals population  imputed method 'frequency' 'HW'. Consider using function  gl.filter.allna .pop=TRUE remove first.

what:
Visualize patterns of linkage disequilibrium and identification of 
haplotypes ‚Äî gl.ld.haplotype
title:
Visualize patterns of linkage disequilibrium and identification of 
haplotypes ‚Äî gl.ld.haplotype
text: function plots Linkage disequilibrium (LD) heatmap, colour  shading indicates strength LD. Chromosome positions (Mbp) shown  horizontal axis, haplotypes appear triangles delimited   dark yellow vertical lines. Numbers identifying haplotype shown   upper part plot. heatmap also shows heterozygosity SNP. function identifies haplotypes based contiguous SNPs   linkage disequilibrium using threshold ld_threshold_haplo containing min_snps SNPs.

title:
Visualize patterns of linkage disequilibrium and identification of 
haplotypes ‚Äî gl.ld.haplotype
code: gl.ld.haplotype(   x,   pop_name = NULL,   chrom_name = NULL,   ld_max_pairwise = 1e+07,   maf = 0.05,   ld_stat = "R.squared",   ind.limit = 10,   min_snps = 10,   ld_threshold_haplo = 0.5,   coordinates = NULL,   color_haplo = "viridis",   color_het = "deeppink",   plot.out = TRUE,   save2tmp = FALSE,   verbose = NULL )

title:
Visualize patterns of linkage disequilibrium and identification of 
haplotypes ‚Äî gl.ld.haplotype
text: x Name genlight object containing SNP data [required]. pop_name Name population analyse. NULL  populations analised [default NULL]. chrom_name Nme chromosome analyse. NULL  chromosomes analised [default NULL]. ld_max_pairwise Maximum distance number base pairs LD calculated [default 10000000]. maf Minor allele frequency (population) threshold filter  loci. value > 1 provided interpreted MAC (.e.  minimum number times allele needs observed) [default 0.05]. ld_stat LD measure calculated: "LLR", "", "Q", "Covar", "D.prime", "R.squared", "R". See ld  (package snpStats) details [default "R.squared"]. ind.limit Minimum number individuals population contain take account report loci LD [default 10]. min_snps Minimum number SNPs haplotype call  [default 10]. ld_threshold_haplo Minimum LD adjacent SNPs call  haplotype [default 0.5]. coordinates vector two elements start end  coordinates base pairs restrict  analysis e.g. c(1,1000000) [default NULL]. color_haplo Color palette haplotype plot. See details [default "viridis"]. color_het Color heterozygosity [default "deeppink"]. plot.Specify heatmap plot produced [default TRUE]. save2tmp TRUE, saves ggplots listings session temporary directory (tempdir) [default FALSE]. verbose Verbosity: 0, silent fatal errors; 1, begin end; 2, progress log; 3, progress results summary; 5, full report [default 2, unless specified using gl.set.verbosity].

title:
Creates an input file for the program NewHybrids and runs it if 
NewHybrids is installed ‚Äî gl.nhybrids
text: function compares two sets parental populations identify loci exhibit fixed difference, returns genlight object reduced data, creates input file program NewHybrids using top 200 (hard specified loc.limit) loci. absence two identified parental populations, script select random set 200 loci (method='random') first 200 loci ranked information content (method='AvgPIC'). fixed difference occurs SNP allele present individuals one population absent . provision setting level tolerance, e.g. threshold = 0.05 considers alleles present greater 95 fixed difference. 200 loci retained, limitations NewHybids. specify directory NewHybrids executable file, script create input file SNP data run NewHybrids. directory set NULL, execution stop input file (default='nhyb.txt') written disk. Note: executable option work Mac; Mac users generate NewHybrids input file run local installation NewHybrids. Refer New Hybrids manual information parameters set -- http://ib.berkeley.edu/labs/slatkin/eriq/software/new_hybs_doc1_1Beta3.pdf important stringently filter data RepAvg CallRate using random option. One might elect repeat analysis (method='random') combine resultant posterior probabilities 200 loci considered insufficient. F1 individuals homozygous loci parental populations fixed different, assuming parental populations specified. Sampling errors can result case, especially sample sizes parental populations small. Alternatively, threshold posterior probabilities used determine assignment (pprob) definition fixed difference (threshold) may lax. assess error rate determination assignment F1 individuals, plot frequency homozygous reference, heterozygotes homozygous alternate (SNP) can produced setting plot=TRUE (default).

Creates an input file for the program NewHybrids and runs it if 
NewHybrids is installed ‚Äî gl.nhybrids
code: gl.nhybrids(   gl,   outpath = tempdir(),   p0 = NULL,   p1 = NULL,   threshold = 0,   method = "random",   plot = TRUE,   plot_theme = theme_dartR(),   plot_colors = two_colors,   pprob = 0.95,   nhyb.directory = NULL,   BurnIn = 10000,   sweeps = 10000,   GtypFile = "TwoGensGtypFreq.txt",   AFPriorFile = NULL,   PiPrior = "Jeffreys",   ThetaPrior = "Jeffreys",   verbose = NULL )

title:
Creates an input file for the program NewHybrids and runs it if 
NewHybrids is installed ‚Äî gl.nhybrids
text: gl Name genlight object containing SNP data [required]. outpath Path save output file [default tempdir()]. p0 List populations regarded parental population 0 [default NULL]. p1 List populations regarded parental population 1 [default NULL]. threshold Sets level gene frequency difference considered fixed [default 0]. method Specifies method (random AvgPIC) select 200 loci NewHybrids [default random]. plot TRUE, plot frequency homozygous reference, heterozygotes homozygous alternate (SNP) produced F1 individuals [default TRUE, applies parental populations specified]. plot_theme User specified theme [default theme_dartR()]. plot_colors Vector two color names borders fill [default two_colors]. pprob Threshold level assignment likelihood bins [default 0.95, used plot=TRUE]. nhyb.directory Directory holds NewHybrids executable file e.g. C:/NewHybsPC [default NULL]. BurnIn Number sweeps use burn [default 10000]. sweeps Number   sweeps   use   computing   actual Monte Carlo averages [default 10000]. GtypFile Name file containing genotype frequency classes [default TwoGensGtypFreq.txt]. AFPriorFile Name file containing prior allele frequency information [default NULL]. PiPrior Jeffreys-like priors Uniform priors parameter pi [default Jeffreys]. ThetaPrior Jeffreys-like priors Uniform priors parameter theta [default Jeffreys]. verbose Verbosity: 0, silent fatal errors; 1, begin end; 2, progress log; 3, progress results summary; 5, full report [default 2 specified using gl.set.verbosity].

title:
Creates an input file for the program NewHybrids and runs it if 
NewHybrids is installed ‚Äî gl.nhybrids
text: reduced genlight object, parentals provided; output  NewHybrids saved working directory.

title:
Creates an input file for the program NewHybrids and runs it if 
NewHybrids is installed ‚Äî gl.nhybrids
text: Anderson, E.C. Thompson, E..(2002). model-based method identifying  species hybrids using multilocus genetic data. Genetics. 160:1217-1229.

title:
Creates an input file for the program NewHybrids and runs it if 
NewHybrids is installed ‚Äî gl.nhybrids
text: Custodian: Arthur Georges -- Post  https://groups.google.com/d/forum/dartr

title:
Creates an input file for the program NewHybrids and runs it if 
NewHybrids is installed ‚Äî gl.nhybrids
code: if (FALSE) { m <- gl.nhybrids(testset.gl,  p0=NULL, p1=NULL, nhyb.directory='D:/workspace/R/NewHybsPC', # Specify as necessary outpath="D:/workspace",  # Specify as necessary, usually getwd() [= workspace] BurnIn=100, sweeps=100, verbose=3) }

title:
Identifies loci under selection per population using the outflank
 method of Whitlock and Lotterhos (2015) ‚Äî gl.outflank
text: gi genlight genind object, defined population structure [required]. plot switch barplot wanted [default TRUE]. LeftTrimFraction proportion loci trimmed lower end range Fst likelihood function applied [default 0.05]. RightTrimFraction proportion loci trimmed upper end range Fst likelihood function applied [default 0.05]. Hmin minimum heterozygosity required including calculations locus [default 0.1]. qthreshold desired false discovery rate threshold calculating q-values [default 0.05]. ... additional parameters (see documentation outflank github).

text: Author(s): Arthur Georges. Custodian: Arthur Georges (Post https://groups.google.com/d/forum/dartr)

title:
Ordination applied to genotypes in a genlight object (PCA), in an fd
object, or to a distance matrix (PCoA) ‚Äî gl.pcoa
code: if (FALSE) { gl <- possums.gl # PCA (using SNP genlight object) pca <- gl.pcoa(possums.gl[1:50,],verbose=2) gl.pcoa.plot(pca,gl)  gs <- testset.gs levels(pop(gs))<-c(rep('Coast',5),rep('Cooper',3),rep('Coast',5), rep('MDB',8),rep('Coast',6),'Em.subglobosa','Em.victoriae')  # PCA (using SilicoDArT genlight object) pca <- gl.pcoa(gs) gl.pcoa.plot(pca,gs)  # Collapsing pops to OTUs using Fixed Difference Analysis (using fd object) fd <- gl.fixed.diff(testset.gl) fd <- gl.collapse(fd) pca <- gl.pcoa(fd) gl.pcoa.plot(pca,fd$gl)  # Using a distance matrix D <- gl.dist.ind(testset.gs, method='jaccard') pcoa <- gl.pcoa(D,correction="cailliez") gl.pcoa.plot(pcoa,gs) }

text: glPca Name PCA PCoA object containing factor scores eigenvalues [required]. x Name genlight object fd object containing SNP genotypes Tag P/(SilicoDArT) genotypes Distance Matrix used generate ordination [required]. scale TRUE, scale x y axes proportion % variation explained [default FALSE]. ellipse TRUE, display ellipses encapsulate points population [default FALSE]. plevel Value percentile ellipse encapsulate points population [default 0.95]. pop.labels labels added plot ['none'|'pop'|'legend', default = 'pop']. interactive TRUE populations plotted without labels, mouse-identify points [default FALSE]. .pop Assign another metric represent populations plot [default NULL]. hadjust Horizontal adjustment label position 2D plots [default 1.5]. vadjust Vertical adjustment label position 2D plots [default 1]. xaxis Identify x axis available ordination (xaxis <= nfactors) [default 1]. yaxis Identify y axis available ordination (yaxis <= nfactors) [default 2]. zaxis Identify z axis available ordination 3D plot (zaxis <= nfactors) [default NULL]. pt.size Specify size displayed points [default 2]. pt.colors Optionally provide vector nPop colors (run gl.select.colors() color options) [default NULL]. pt.shapes Optionally provide vector nPop shapes (run gl.select.shapes() shape options) [default NULL]. label.size Specify size point labels [default 1]. axis.label.size Specify size displayed axis labels [default 1.5]. save2tmp TRUE, saves ggplots listings session temporary directory (tempdir) [default FALSE]. verbose Verbosity: 0, silent fatal errors; 1, begin end; 2, progress log; 3, progress results summary; 5, full report  [default 2 specified using gl.set.verbosity].

title: Reads SNP data from a csv file into a genlight object ‚Äî gl.read.csv
text: filename Name csv file containing SNP genotypes [required]. transpose TRUE, rows loci columns individuals [default FALSE]. ind.metafile Name csv file containing metrics individuals [optional]. loc.metafile Name csv file containing metrics loci [optional]. verbose Verbosity: 0, silent fatal errors; 1, begin end; 2, progress log; 3, progress results summary; 5, full report [default 2 specified using gl.set.verbosity].

title: Reads SNP data from a csv file into a genlight object ‚Äî gl.read.csv
text: genlight object SNP data associated metadata included.

title: Reads SNP data from a csv file into a genlight object ‚Äî gl.read.csv
text: SNP data need one two forms. SNPs can coded 0 homozygous reference, 2 homozygous alternate, 1 heterozygous, NA  missing values; SNP data can coded /, /C, C/T, G/etc, -/- missing data. format, reference allele  frequent allele, used DArT. formats throw error. SNP data need individuals rows, labeled, loci columns, also labeled. orientation individuals columns loci rows,  set transpose=TRUE. individual metrics need csv file, headings,  mandatory id column corresponding exactly individual identity labels  provided SNP data order. locus metadata needs csv file headings, mandatory column headed AlleleID corresponding exactly locus identity labels provided SNP data order. Note locus metadata complemented calculable statistics corresponding provided Diversity Arrays Technology (e.g. CallRate).

text: gl.read.silicodart() opens data file (csv comma delimited) skips first n=topskip lines. script assumes next line contains entity labels (specimen ids) followed immediately SNP data first locus. reads presence/absence data matrix 1s 0s, inputs  locus metadata specimen metadata. locus metadata comprises series  columns values locus including essential columns  CloneID desirable variables Reproducibility PIC. Refer   documentation provide DArT explanation columns. specimen metadata provides opportunity reassign specimens  populations, add data relevant specimen. key  variables id (specimen identity must  order SilicoDArT file, unique), pop (population assignment), lat  (latitude, optional) lon (longitude, optional). id, pop, lat, lon  column headers csv file. optional columns can added. data matrix, locus names (forced unique), locus metadata, specimen  names, specimen metadata combined genind object. Refer  documentation {adegenet} details.

title:
Reports observed, expected and unbiased heterozygosities and FIS
(inbreeding coefficient) by population or by individual from SNP data ‚Äî gl.report.heterozygosity
text: Observed heterozygosity population takes proportion heterozygous loci individual averages individuals population. calculations take account missing values. Expected heterozygosity population takes expected proportion heterozygotes, , expected Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, locus, averages across loci average estimate population. Observed heterozygosity individuals calculated proportion loci heterozygous individual. Finally, loci invariant across individuals dataset (, across populations), typically unknown. can render estimates heterozygosity analysis specific, valid compare estimates across species even across different analyses. similar problem faced microsatellites. estimate number invariant sequence tags (loci) data, provided gl.report.secondaries, can specify n.invariant parameter standardize estimates heterozygosity. NOTE: important realise estimation adjusted heterozygosity requires secondaries removed. Heterozygosities FIS (inbreeding coefficient) calculated locus within population using following equations: Observed heterozygosity (Ho) = number homozygotes / n_Ind, n_Ind number individuals without missing data. Observed heterozygosity adjusted (Ho.adj) <- Ho * n_Loc /  (n_Loc + n.invariant), n_Loc number loci missing data  n.invariant estimate number invariant loci adjust heterozygosity. Expected heterozygosity () = 1 - (p^2 + q^2), p frequency reference allele q frequency alternative allele. Expected heterozygosity adjusted (.adj) = * n_Loc / (n_Loc + n.invariant) Unbiased expected heterozygosity (uHe) = * (2 * n_Ind / (2 * n_Ind - 1)) Inbreeding coefficient (FIS) = 1 - (mean(Ho) / mean(uHe)) Function's output Output method='pop' ordered barchart observed heterozygosity, expected heterozygosity FIS (Inbreeding coefficient) across populations together table mean observed expected heterozygosities FIS population respective standard deviations (SD). Output method='ind' histogram boxplot heterozygosity across individuals. Plots table saved session temporary directory (tempdir) Examples themes can used can consulted https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/ggtheme.html https://yutannihilation.github.io/allYourFigureAreBelongToUs/ggthemes/

title: Reports departure from Hardy-Weinberg proportions ‚Äî gl.report.hwe
text: several factors can cause deviations Hardy-Weinberg  proportions including: mutation, finite population size, selection,  population structure, age structure, assortative mating, sex linkage,  nonrandom sampling genotyping errors. Therefore, testing  Hardy-Weinberg proportions process involves careful  evaluation results, good place start Waples (2015). Note tests H-W proportions valid population  substructure (assuming random mating) sufficient power  sufficient sample size (n individuals > 15). Populations can defined three ways: Merging populations dataset using subset = ''. Within population separately using: subset = ''. Within selected populations using example: subset =  c('pop1','pop2'). Two different statistical methods test deviations Hardy Weinberg proportions: classical chi-square test (method_sig='ChiSquare') based function HWChisq R package HardyWeinberg. default continuity correction applied (cc_val=0.5). continuity correction can turned (specifying cc_val=0), example cases extreme allele frequencies continuity correction can lead excessive type 1 error rates. exact test (method_sig='Exact') based exact calculations contained function HWExactStats R package HardyWeinberg, described Wigginton  et al. (2005). exact test recommended cases (Wigginton  et al., 2005). Three different methods estimate p-values (pvalue_type) Exact test can used: 'dost' p-value computed twice tail area one-sided test. 'selome' p-value computed sum probabilities samples less equally likely current sample. 'midp', p-value computed half probability current sample + probabilities samples extreme. standard exact p-value overly conservative, particular small minor allele frequencies. mid p-value ameliorates problem bringing rejection rate closer nominal level, price occasionally exceeding nominal level (Graffelman & Moreno, 2013). Correction multiple tests can applied using following methods based function p.adjust: 'holm' also known sequential Bonferroni technique (Rice, 1989). method greater statistical power standard Bonferroni test, however method becomes stringent many tests performed many real deviations null hypothesis can go  undetected (Waples, 2015). 'hochberg' based Hochberg, 1988. 'hommel' based Hommel, 1988. method powerful  Hochberg's, difference usually small. 'bonferroni' p-values multiplied number tests. method stringent therefore reduced power detect multiple departures null hypothesis. 'BH' based Benjamini & Hochberg, 1995. '' based Benjamini & Yekutieli, 2001. first four methods designed give strong control family-wise error rate. last two methods control false discovery rate (FDR), expected proportion false discoveries among rejected hypotheses. false discovery rate less stringent condition family-wise error rate, methods powerful others, especially number tests large. number tests adjustment multiple comparisons number populations times number loci. Ternary plots Ternary plots can used visualise patterns H-W proportions (plot.= TRUE). P-values statistical (non)significance large number bi-allelic markers can inferred position ternary plot. See Graffelman & Morales-Camarena (2008) details. Ternary plots based function  HWTernaryPlot package HardyWeinberg. vertex Ternary plot represents one  three possible genotypes SNP data: homozygous reference  allele (AA), heterozygous (AB) homozygous alternative allele  (BB). Loci deviating significantly Hardy-Weinberg proportions   correction multiple tests shown pink. blue parabola   represents Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, area green lines   represents acceptance region. plots work necessary install package ggtern.

Waples, R. S. (2015). Testing Hardy‚ÄìWeinberg proportions: lost plot?. Journal heredity, 106(1), 1-19. Wigginton, J.E., Cutler, D.J., & Abecasis, G.R. (2005). what: Calculates pairwise linkage disequilibrium by population ‚Äî gl.report.ld.map
title: Calculates pairwise linkage disequilibrium by population ‚Äî gl.report.ld.map
text: function calculates pairwise linkage disequilibrium (LD) population  using function ld (package snpStats). SNPs mapped reference genome, parameter  ld_max_pairwise  set NULL (default). case,  function assign chromosome ("1") SNPs dataset  assign sequence 1 n loci position SNP.   function calculate LD possible SNP pair combinations. SNPs mapped reference genome, parameter  ld_max_pairwise  filled (.e. NULL). case,  information SNP's position stored genlight accessor   "@position" SNP's chromosome name accessor "@chromosome"    (see examples). function calculate LD within chromosome     possible SNP pair combinations within distance      ld_max_pairwise.

title: Calculates pairwise linkage disequilibrium by population ‚Äî gl.report.ld.map
code: gl.report.ld.map(   x,   ld_max_pairwise = NULL,   maf = 0.05,   ld_stat = "R.squared",   ind.limit = 10,   stat_keep = "AvgPIC",   ld_threshold_pops = 0.2,   plot.out = TRUE,   plot_theme = NULL,   histogram_colors = NULL,   boxplot_colors = NULL,   bins = 50,   save2tmp = FALSE,   verbose = NULL )

title: Calculates pairwise linkage disequilibrium by population ‚Äî gl.report.ld.map
text: x Name genlight object containing SNP data [required]. ld_max_pairwise Maximum distance number base pairs LD  calculated [default NULL]. maf Minor allele frequency (population) threshold filter  loci. value > 1 provided interpreted MAC (.e.  minimum number times allele needs observed) [default 0.05]. ld_stat LD measure calculated: "LLR", "", "Q", "Covar", "D.prime", "R.squared", "R". See ld  (package snpStats) details [default "R.squared"]. ind.limit Minimum number individuals population contain take account report loci LD [default 10]. stat_keep Name column slot loc.metrics used choose SNP kept [default "AvgPIC"]. ld_threshold_pops LD threshold report plot "Number  populations SNP pair LD" [default 0.2]. plot.Specify plot produced [default TRUE]. plot_theme User specified theme [default NULL]. histogram_colors Vector two color names borders fill [default NULL]. boxplot_colors color palette box plots population list  many colors populations dataset [default NULL]. bins Number bins display histograms [default 50]. save2tmp TRUE, saves ggplots listings session temporary directory (tempdir) [default FALSE]. verbose Verbosity: 0, silent fatal errors; 1, begin end; 2, progress log; 3, progress results summary; 5, full report [default 2, unless specified using gl.set.verbosity].

title: Calculates pairwise linkage disequilibrium by population ‚Äî gl.report.ld.map
code: x <- platypus.gl x <- gl.filter.callrate(x,threshold = 1) #> Starting gl.filter.callrate  #>   Processing genlight object with SNP data #>   Warning: data include loci that are scored NA across all individuals. #>   Consider filtering using gl <- gl.filter.allna(gl) #>   Warning: Data may include monomorphic loci in call rate  #>                     calculations for filtering #>   Recalculating Call Rate #>   Removing loci based on Call Rate, threshold = 1  #>   #> Completed: gl.filter.callrate  #>  x$position <- x$other$loc.metrics$ChromPos_Platypus_Chrom_NCBIv1 x$chromosome <- as.factor(x$other$loc.metrics$Chrom_Platypus_Chrom_NCBIv1) ld_res <- gl.report.ld.map(x,ld_max_pairwise = 10000000) #> Starting gl.report.ld.map  #>   Processing genlight object with SNP data #>   Calculating pairwise LD in population SEVERN_ABOVE  #>   Calculating pairwise LD in population SEVERN_BELOW  #>   Calculating pairwise LD in population TENTERFIELD  #>   #> Completed: gl.report.ld.map  #>

title: Reports summary of the slot $other$loc.metrics ‚Äî gl.report.locmetric
text: function gl.filter.locmetric filter  loci locmetric value specified threshold. fields included dartR, short description, found . Optionally, user can also set /field adding vector $$loc.metrics shown example. can check names available loc.metrics via: names(gl$$loc.metrics). SnpPosition - position (zero position 1) sequence tag defined SNP variant base. CallRate - proportion samples genotype call non-missing (, '-' ). OneRatioRef - proportion samples genotype score 0. OneRatioSnp - proportion samples genotype score 2. FreqHomRef - proportion samples homozygous Reference allele. FreqHomSnp - proportion samples homozygous Alternate (SNP) allele. FreqHets - proportion samples score heterozygous, , scored 1. PICRef - polymorphism information content (PIC) Reference allele. PICSnp - polymorphism information content (PIC) SNP. AvgPIC - average polymorphism information content (PIC) reference SNP alleles. AvgCountRef - sum tag read counts samples, divided number samples non-zero tag read counts, Reference allele row. AvgCountSnp - sum tag read counts samples, divided number samples non-zero tag read counts, Alternate (SNP) allele row. RepAvg - proportion technical replicate assay pairs marker score consistent. rdepth - read depth. Function's output minimum, maximum, mean tabulation quantiles locmetric values thresholds rate provided. Output also includes boxplot histogram. Quantiles partitions finite set values q subsets (nearly) equal sizes. function q = 20. Quantiles useful measures less susceptible long-tailed distributions outliers. Plots table saved temporal directory (tempdir) can  accessed function gl.print.reports listed  function gl.list.reports. Note can accessed  current R session tempdir cleared time  R session closed. Examples themes can used can consulted : https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/ggtheme.html https://yutannihilation.github.io/allYourFigureAreBelongToUs/ggthemes/

title: Reports private alleles (and fixed alleles) per pair of populations ‚Äî gl.report.pa
text: Note number paired alleles two populations symmetric dissimilarity measure. x2 provided, function uses pop(gl) hierarchy determine pairs populations, otherwise runs single comparison x x2. Hint: case want run comparisons individuals (assuming individual names unique), can simply redefine population names individual names, : pop(gl) <- indNames(gl) Definition fixed private alleles table shows possible cases allele frequencies two populations (0 = homozygote Allele 1, x = Alleles present, 1 = homozygote Allele 2). p: cases private allele pop1 compared pop2 (vice versa) f: cases fixed allele pop1 (pop2, cases symmetric) absolute allele frequency difference (AFD) function simple differentiation metric displaying intuitive properties provides valuable alternative FST. details properties calculated see Berner (2019). function Sankey Diagram used visualize patterns private alleles populations. diagram allows display flows (private alleles) nodes (populations). links represented arcs width proportional importance flow (number private alleles). save2temp=TRUE, resultant plot(s) tabulation(s) saved session's temporary directory.

title: Reports private alleles (and fixed alleles) per pair of populations ‚Äî gl.report.pa
text: Berner, D. (2019). Allele frequency difference AFD ‚Äì intuitive alternative FST quantifying genetic population differentiation. Genes,  10(4), 308.

text: function gl.filter.secondaries filter   loci secondaries retaining one sequence tag. Heterozygosity estimated function   gl.report.heterozygosity sense relative,   calculated background loci polymorphic   somewhere dataset. allow intercompatibility across studies   species, measure heterozygosity needs accommodate loci   invariant (autosomal heterozygosity. See Schmidt et al 2021). However,   number invariant loci unknown given SNPs detected single   point mutational variants invariant sequences discarded,   particular additional filtering pre-analysis. Modelling   counts SNPs per sequence tag Poisson distribution script   allows estimate zero class, , number invariant loci.   reported, veracity estimate can assessed   correspondence observed frequencies Poisson   expectation associated graphs. number invariant loci can   optionally provided function   gl.report.heterozygosity via parameter n.invariants. case calculations Poisson expectation number   invariant sequence tags fail converge, try rerun analysis   larger nsim values. function now also calculates number invariant sites (.e.   nucleotides) sequence tags (TrimmedSequence present   x$$loc.metrics) estimate assuming average   length sequence tags 69 nucleotides. Based Poisson   expectation number invariant sequence tags, also estimates   number invariant sites eventually provide estimate   total number invariant sites. Note, previous version   dartR return estimate number invariant   sequence tags (sites). Plots saved session temporary directory (tempdir). title: Runs a STRUCTURE analysis using a genlight object ‚Äî gl.run.structure
code: gl.run.structure(   x,   ...,   exec = ".",   plot.out = TRUE,   plot_theme = theme_dartR(),   save2tmp = FALSE,   verbose = NULL )

title: Runs a STRUCTURE analysis using a genlight object ‚Äî gl.run.structure
text: x Name genlight object containing SNP data [required]. ... Parameters specify STRUCTURE run (check structureRun  within strataG. details). Parameters passed structureRun function. example need set k.range type model like run (noadmix, locprior) etc. parameter names tell anything, please make sure familiarize STRUCTURE program (Pritchard 2000). exec Full path name+extension structure executable located. E.g. 'c:/structure/structure.exe' Windows. Mac Linux might something like './structure/structure' executable subfolder 'structure' home directory [default working directory "."]. plot.Create Evanno plot finished. aware k.range needs least three different k steps [default TRUE]. plot_theme Theme plot. See details options [default theme_dartR()]. save2tmp TRUE, saves ggplots listings session temporary directory (tempdir) [default FALSE]. verbose Set verbosity function (though structure output switched currently) [default NULL]

title: Runs a STRUCTURE analysis using a genlight object ‚Äî gl.run.structure
text: sr object (structure.result list output). list entry single structurerun output (k.range * num.k.rep number runs). example summary output first run can accessed via sr[[1]]$summary q-matrix third run via sr[[3]]$q.mat. conveniently summarise outputs across runs (clumpp) need run gl.plot.structure returned sr object. Evanno plots run gl.evanno sr object.

title: Runs a STRUCTURE analysis using a genlight object ‚Äî gl.run.structure
text: function basically convenient wrapper around beautiful strataG function structureRun (Archer et al. 2016). detailed description please refer package (see references ). make use function need download STRUCTURE system (non GUI version) STRUCTURE.

title: Runs a STRUCTURE analysis using a genlight object ‚Äî gl.run.structure
text: Pritchard, J.K., Stephens, M., Donnelly, P. (2000) Inference population structure using multilocus genotype data. Genetics 155, 945-959. Archer, F. ., Adams, P. E. Schneiders, B. B. (2016) strataG: R package manipulating, summarizing analysing population genetic data.  Mol Ecol Resour. doi:10.1111/1755-0998.12559

title: Selects colors from one of several palettes and output as a vector ‚Äî gl.select.colors
code: # SET UP DATASET gl <- testset.gl levels(pop(gl))<-c(rep('Coast',5),rep('Cooper',3),rep('Coast',5), rep('MDB',8),rep('Coast',7),'Em.subglobosa','Em.victoriae') # EXAMPLES -- SIMPLE colors <- gl.select.colors() #> Starting gl.select.colors  #>   Warning: Number of required colors not specified, set to 9 to display the colors #>   Warning: No color library or palette specified, set to default #>     Select one of baseR, brewer, gr.palette or gr.hcl #>   Library: scale #>   Palette: hue_pal #>   Showing and returning 9 colors for library scales : palette hue_pal   #> Completed: gl.select.colors  #>  colors <- gl.select.colors(library='brewer',palette='Spectral',ncolors=6) #> Starting gl.select.colors  #>   Library: RColorBrewer #>   Palette: brewer.pal #>   Showing and returning 6 colors for library RColorBrewer : palette Spectral   #> Completed: gl.select.colors  #>  colors <- gl.select.colors(library='baseR',palette='terrain.colors',ncolors=6) #> Starting gl.select.colors  #>   Library: baseR #>   Palette: terrain.colors #>   Showing and returning 6 colors for library baseR : palette terrain.colors   #> Completed: gl.select.colors  #>  colors <- gl.select.colors(library='baseR',palette='rainbow',ncolors=12) #> Starting gl.select.colors  #>   Library: baseR #>   Palette: rainbow #>   Showing and returning 12 colors for library baseR : palette rainbow   #> Completed: gl.select.colors  #>  colors <- gl.select.colors(library='gr.hcl',palette='RdBu',ncolors=12) #> Starting gl.select.colors  #>   Library: grDevices #>   Palette: hcl.pals #>   Showing and returning 12 colors for library grDevice-hcl : palette RdBu   #> Completed: gl.select.colors  #>  colors <- gl.select.colors(library='gr.palette',palette='Pastel 1',ncolors=6) #> Starting gl.select.colors  #>   Library: grDevices #>   Palette: palette.pals #>   Showing and returning 6 colors for library grDevice-palette : palette Pastel 1   #> Completed: gl.select.colors  #>  # EXAMPLES -- SELECTING colorS colors <- gl.select.colors(library='baseR',palette='rainbow',ncolors=12,select=c(1,1,1,5,8)) #> Starting gl.select.colors  #>   Library: baseR #>   Palette: rainbow #>   Showing and returning 5 of 12 colors for library baseR : palette rainbow   #> Completed: gl.select.colors  #>  # EXAMPLES -- CROSS-CHECKING WITH A GENLIGHT OBJECT colors <- gl.select.colors(x=gl,library='baseR',palette='rainbow',ncolors=12,select=c(1,1,1,5,8)) #> Starting gl.select.colors  #>   Processing genlight object with SNP data #>   Number of specified colors 5 corresponds to number of populations in supplied genlight object #>   Library: baseR #>   Palette: rainbow #>   Showing and returning 5 of 12 colors for library baseR : palette rainbow  #> Completed: gl.select.colors  #>

Simulations can recreate specific life histories demographics,  source populations, dispersal rate, number generations, founder   individuals, effective population size census population size. allele individual agent (.e., allele  explicitly simulated). locus can customisable regarding allele frequencies,  selection coefficients, dominance. number loci, individuals, populations simulated  limited computing resources. title: Simulates emigration between populations ‚Äî gl.sim.emigration
text: x genlight list genlight objects [required]. perc.mig Percentage individuals migrate (emigrates = nInd times perc.mig) [default NULL]. emi.m Probabilistic emigration matrix (emigrate =column =row) [default NULL] emi.table presented emi.m matrix ignored. Deterministic emigration specified matrix (square matrix dimension number populations). e.g. entry 'emi.table[2,1]<- 5' means five individuals emigrate population 1 population 2 (=columns  =row) [default NULL].

title: Simulates emigration between populations ‚Äî gl.sim.emigration
text: list single [depends input] genlight object, emigration population happened

title: Simulates emigration between populations ‚Äî gl.sim.emigration
text: two ways specify emigration. emi.table provided (square matrix dimension populations specifies emigration column x row y), emigration deterministic terms numbers individuals specified table. perc.mig emi.m provided, emigration probabilistic. number emigrants determined population size times perc.mig population migrate taken relative probability columns emi.m table. aware diagonal non zero migration can occur patch. often want set diagonal emi.m matrix zero. individuals moved random, order order populations. possible individual moves twice within emigration call(check, individual moved population 1 2 can move population 2 3).

title: Simulates emigration between populations ‚Äî gl.sim.emigration
code: x <- possums.gl #one individual moves from every population to #every other population emi.tab <- matrix(1, nrow=nPop(x), ncol=nPop(x)) diag(emi.tab)<- 0 np <- gl.sim.emigration(x, emi.table=emi.tab) np #>  /// GENLIGHT OBJECT ///////// #>  #>  // 300 genotypes,  200 binary SNPs, size: 508.5 Kb #>  0 (0 %) missing data #>  #>  // Basic content #>    @gen: list of 300 SNPbin #>  #>  // Optional content #>    @ind.names:  300 individual labels #>    @loc.names:  200 locus labels #>    @pop: population of each individual (group size range: 30-30) #>    @other: a list containing: elements without names  #>

text: Bernd Gruber (bernd.gruber@canberra.edu.au)

title:
Simulates individuals based on the allele frequencies provided via a genlight
object. ‚Äî gl.sim.ind
code: glsim <- gl.sim.ind(testset.gl, n=10, popname='sims') glsim #>  /// GENLIGHT OBJECT ///////// #>  #>  // 10 genotypes,  255 binary SNPs, size: 43.3 Kb #>  0 (0 %) missing data #>  #>  // Basic content #>    @gen: list of 10 SNPbin #>    @ploidy: ploidy of each individual  (range: 2-2) #>  #>  // Optional content #>    @ind.names:  10 individual labels #>    @loc.names:  255 locus labels #>    @loc.all:  255 alleles #>    @position: integer storing positions of the SNPs #>    @pop: population of each individual (group size range: 10-10) #>    @other: a list containing: elements without names  #>  ###Simulate drift over 10 generation # assuming a bottleneck of only 10 individuals # [ignoring effect of mating and mutation] # Simulate 20 individuals with no structure and 50 SNP loci founder <- glSim(n.ind = 20, n.snp.nonstruc = 50, ploidy=2) #number of fixed loci in the first generation  res <- sum(colMeans(as.matrix(founder), na.rm=TRUE) %%2 ==0) simgl <- founder #49 generations of only 10 individuals for (i in 2:50) {    simgl <- gl.sim.ind(simgl, n=10, popname='sims')    res[i]<- sum(colMeans(as.matrix(simgl), na.rm=TRUE) %%2 ==0) } plot(1:50, res, type='b', xlab='generation', ylab='# fixed loci')
